åŸå§‹ä¿¡æ¯

CVE-2025-26892 â€“ WordPress Celestial Aura Theme <= 2.2 Arbitrary File Upload (Authenticated)

ğŸ“„ Description

An Unrestricted File Upload vulnerability exists in the WordPress Celestial Aura theme (developed by dkszone) up to version 2.2.
A low-privileged authenticated user can upload arbitrary PHP files through the themeâ€™s admin panel, potentially leading to Remote Code Execution (RCE).

  • Affected theme: Celestial Aura
  • Affected versions: â‰¤ 2.2
  • Vulnerable file: wp-admin/admin.php?page=CA-settings
  • Exploitable by: Any authenticated user (subscriber and above)
  • No nonce, file type, or extension validation

ğŸ›¡ï¸ CVSS Score

Patchstack CNA Rating:

  • Base Score: 9.9 (CRITICAL)
  • Vector: CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:L/UI:N/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H

ğŸš€ Usage

The script logs in with the provided credentials, uploads a malicious PHP shell (nxploit.php) via the vulnerable theme settings, and prints the direct URL to the uploaded shell.

âœ… Successful Exploit Output

âš ï¸ Disclaimer

This project is for educational and authorized penetration testing purposes only.
Any misuse of this tool is not the responsibility of the author.

æ¼æ´ä¿¡æ¯

æ¼æ´åç§°ï¼š WordPress Nasa Core Plugin æœ¬åœ°æ–‡ä»¶åŒ…å«æ¼æ´

æ¼æ´ç¼–å·ï¼š

  • CVEï¼š CVE-2025-39507

æ¼æ´ç±»å‹ï¼š æ–‡ä»¶åŒ…å«

æ¼æ´ç­‰çº§ï¼š é«˜å±

æ¼æ´æè¿°ï¼š WordPressçš„Nasa Coreæ’ä»¶ï¼ˆç‰ˆæœ¬6.3.2åŠä»¥ä¸‹ï¼‰å­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªæœ¬åœ°æ–‡ä»¶åŒ…å«æ¼æ´ï¼ˆCVE-2025-39507ï¼‰ã€‚æ”»å‡»è€…å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡æ“çºµæ–‡ä»¶è¾“å…¥å‚æ•°æ¥è®¿é—®æœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸Šçš„æ•æ„Ÿæ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚é€šè¿‡æ„é€ ç‰¹å®šçš„URLè·¯å¾„ï¼ˆå¦‚/index.php?file=../../../../etc/passwdï¼‰æ¥å°è¯•è¯»å–ç³»ç»Ÿæ–‡ä»¶ã€‚è¯¥æ¼æ´æºäºæ’ä»¶æœªèƒ½æ­£ç¡®éªŒè¯æ–‡ä»¶è¾“å…¥ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´æ”»å‡»è€…å¯ä»¥æŒ‡å®šä»»æ„è·¯å¾„è¿›è¡Œæ–‡ä»¶åŒ…å«æ“ä½œã€‚

äº§å“å‚å•†ï¼š WordPress

äº§å“åç§°ï¼š Nasa Core Plugin

å½±å“ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼š <= 6.3.2

æ¥æºï¼š https://github.com/blackgirlinfosec/cve-lfi-lab

ç±»å‹ï¼š CVE-2025:github search

ä»“åº“æ–‡ä»¶

  • README.md

åŸå§‹ä¿¡æ¯

ğŸ§  CVE Lab: Tier 1 SOC Analyst Simulation

CVE-2025-39507 | Local File Inclusion in WordPress Nasa Core Plugin

ğŸ“ Scenario: A Day in the SOC

Itâ€™s a regular Monday. Iâ€™m logged into the SOC dashboard, reviewing alerts like usual. One comes in that catches my eye:

ALERT: Possible Local File Inclusion (LFI) Attempt
IP Address: 203.0.113.44
URL: /index.php?file=../../../../etc/passwd
User Agent: curl/7.81.0

It looks like someone might be trying to access system files by manipulating a URL. My job is to look into it and decide if this needs to be escalated.

ğŸ” Background on the CVE

After some quick research, I found this matches a known vulnerability: CVE-2025-39507. It affects a WordPress plugin called Nasa Core (version 6.3.2 and below). It allows attackers to view sensitive files on the server by changing a file input parameter.

Example:

If the plugin doesnâ€™t validate the file input correctly, itâ€™ll just follow whatever path the attacker gives it.

ğŸ› ï¸ My Tier 1 Investigation

1. Checked the Alert in Sentinel

I didnâ€™t write the detection rule, but I reviewed it to understand what triggered the alert. It looks for things like:

  • URLs with â€œ../â€ (path traversal)
  • Requests to sensitive files like /etc/passwd or /wp-config.php
  • Scripts or tools in the user agent (like curl or Python)

Hereâ€™s a simplified version of the rule:

2. Looked Up the IP Address

I ran a query to see if the IP 203.0.113.44 was trying anything else:

Turns out, it also hit other paths like /admin/, /login.php, and /wp-config.php. That told me this wasnâ€™t just a one-time request â€” it was probably a scanner or someone doing recon.

3. Checked the Timeline

I checked how long the IP had been active in our logs:

It started a few hours ago and was still active recently. So it wasnâ€™t historical noise â€” this was ongoing.

4. Escalated to Tier 2

Hereâ€™s how I documented it for escalation:

â€œPossible LFI scan from IP 203.0.113.44. The request pattern matches CVE-2025-39507. IP accessed 9 unique paths including /etc/passwd and wp-config.php using curl. Behavior suggests automated recon. Recommend Tier 2 review and possible IP block.â€

ğŸ“¸ Screenshots

#DescriptionFile
1CVE Listing (Patchstack)1_cve_selection_listing.png
2Patchstack Overview2_patchstack_cve_overview.png
3VulDB Vector Example3_vuldb_exploit_vector.png
4Azure Kali VM Created4_kali_vm_deployed.png
5VM Running Screenshot5_kali_vm_running_status.png
6SSH Access to Kali6_kali_vm_logged_in.png
7Sentinel KQL Rule Review7_lfi_detection_kql_query.png

All screenshots are located in the /screenshots folder.

ğŸ” Reflection

Some questions I asked myself as I worked through this:

  • What signs in the logs made this alert stand out?
  • How can I tell if this is just a scanner or something more serious?
  • What else might happen if this LFI attack actually succeeded?
  • Whatâ€™s the right balance between alert fatigue and escalation?

ğŸ”œ Whatâ€™s Next â€“ Phase 2

Next, Iâ€™ll run a safe simulation of this attack in a controlled lab environment using a platform like TryHackMe. The goal is to better understand what this type of activity looks like from the attackerâ€™s side â€” and what kind of logs it creates.

âš ï¸ Disclaimer

This lab was done in a safe, ethical environment for training purposes only. No real systems were targeted or harmed. Always follow your organizationâ€™s rules and never test exploits on systems you donâ€™t own or have permission to test.

æ¼æ´åç§°ï¼š WordPress File Away ä»»æ„æ–‡ä»¶è¯»å–æ¼æ´

  • CVEï¼š CVE-2025-2539

æ¼æ´ç±»å‹ï¼š æ–‡ä»¶è¯»å–

æ¼æ´ç­‰çº§ï¼š ä¸¥é‡

æ¼æ´æè¿°ï¼š WordPressæ’ä»¶File Awayç‰ˆæœ¬<=3.9.9.0.1å­˜åœ¨æœªè®¤è¯çš„ä»»æ„æ–‡ä»¶è¯»å–æ¼æ´ã€‚æ”»å‡»è€…å¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡å‘æ’ä»¶çš„AJAXç«¯ç‚¹å‘é€ç‰¹åˆ¶è¯·æ±‚æ¥è¯»å–æœåŠ¡å™¨ä¸Šçš„ä»»ä½•æ–‡ä»¶ï¼Œå¦‚wp-config.phpã€‚æ¼æ´æºäºä½¿ç”¨fileaway-statsåŠ¨ä½œé€šè¿‡admin-ajax.phpæ—¶çš„ä¸å½“nonceéªŒè¯å’Œè·¯å¾„é™åˆ¶ç¼ºå¤±ã€‚æ”»å‡»è€…å¯åˆ©ç”¨æ­¤æ¼æ´æ£€ç´¢æ•æ„Ÿæ–‡ä»¶å¹¶æå–å‡­è¯ï¼Œå¯èƒ½å¯¼è‡´å®Œå…¨å¦¥åã€‚

äº§å“å‚å•†ï¼š WordPress

äº§å“åç§°ï¼š File Away

å½±å“ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼š <= 3.9.9.0.1

æ¥æºï¼š https://github.com/Yucaerin/CVE-2025-2539

ç±»å‹ï¼š CVE-2025:github search

ä»“åº“æ–‡ä»¶

  • mass_cve_2539.py
  • readme.md

åŸå§‹ä¿¡æ¯

CVE-2025-2539 - WordPress File Away <= 3.9.9.0.1 - Arbitrary File Read

ğŸ”¥ Vulnerability Summary
The WordPress plugin File Away version <= 3.9.9.0.1 is vulnerable to an unauthenticated arbitrary file read vulnerability.
This allows attackers to read any file on the server, such as wp-config.php, through a crafted request to the pluginâ€™s AJAX endpoint.

The vulnerability stems from improper nonce validation and lack of path restriction when using the fileaway-stats action via admin-ajax.php.
Attackers can leverage this to retrieve sensitive files and extract credentials, potentially leading to full compromise.

ğŸ” Affected Plugin

  • Plugin Name: File Away
  • Affected Version: <= 3.9.9.0.1
  • Vulnerability Type: Unauthenticated Arbitrary File Read
  • CVE ID: CVE-2025-2539
  • CVSS Score: 9.1 (Critical)
  • Impact: Sensitive Information Disclosure â†’ Potential RCE (via DB creds + upload)

ğŸ§ª Exploit Features

  • ğŸ“¥ Fetches nonce automatically from the target page
  • ğŸ“„ Reads arbitrary file (e.g., wp-config.php)
  • ğŸ” Extracts DB credentials (DB_USER, DB_PASSWORD, DB_HOST)
  • âœ… Validates access to /phpmyadmin or /phpMyAdmin
  • ğŸŒ Attempts remote DB login using retrieved credentials
  • ğŸ’¾ Stores valid credentials and phpMyAdmin access in:
    • result_database.txt
    • result_phpmyadmin_dan_config_valid.txt
    • result_databaseremotevalid.txt

ğŸ§  Researcher
Credit: https://github.com/RootHarpy/CVE-2025-2539

ğŸš€ Usage
Prepare your list.txt file with a list of target domains (one per line, without http or https).

Example list.txt:

Run the script:

ğŸ“ Output

  • result_database.txt â†’ List of extracted DB credentials
  • result_phpmyadmin_and_config_valid.txt â†’ List of phpMyAdmin URLs found
  • result_databaseremotevalid.txt â†’ List of valid remote DB credentials

ğŸ”’ Disclaimer:
This tool is intended for educational purposes only and should only be used on systems you own or are explicitly authorized to test. Misuse of this code may lead to legal consequences.

entry.title: Cisco ISE Cloud Credential Sharing Vulnerability
entry.content:
æ¼æ´ä¿¡æ¯

æ³¨: æœ¬æ¨¡å—æ¥è‡ª AI å¯èƒ½å­˜åœ¨é”™è¯¯

æ¼æ´åç§°ï¼š Cisco ISE Cloud Credential Sharing Vulnerability

æ¼æ´ç¼–å·ï¼š

  • CVEï¼š CVE-2025-20286

æ¼æ´ç±»å‹ï¼š ä¿¡æ¯æ³„éœ²

æ¼æ´ç­‰çº§ï¼š ä¸¥é‡

æ¼æ´æè¿°ï¼š Cisco ISEäº‘éƒ¨ç½²åœ¨AWSã€Microsoft Azureå’ŒOracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI)ä¸Šå­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªä¸¥é‡çš„å‡­è¯ç”Ÿæˆå’Œæˆæƒé€»è¾‘ç¼ºé™·ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´ä½¿ç”¨ç›¸åŒè½¯ä»¶ç‰ˆæœ¬çš„äº‘éƒ¨ç½²å…±äº«ç›¸åŒçš„å‡­è¯ã€‚è¿™ä½¿å¾—æœªç»è®¤è¯çš„è¿œç¨‹æ”»å‡»è€…èƒ½å¤Ÿæå–æœ‰æ•ˆå‡­è¯å¹¶åœ¨ä¸åŒéƒ¨ç½²é—´æå‡æƒé™ã€‚

äº§å“å‚å•†ï¼š Cisco

äº§å“åç§°ï¼š Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE)

æ¥æºï¼š https://github.com/amandanegefa/CVE-2025-20286

ç±»å‹ï¼š CVE-2025:github search

ä»“åº“æ–‡ä»¶

  • README.md

åŸå§‹ä¿¡æ¯

Zero-Day Expl0it for Cisco ISE Cloud Credential Sharing Vulnerability (CVE-2025-20286)

All materials included in this repository are collected from publicly available sources.

Severity: Critical (CVSS 9.9)

Affected Platforms: Cisco Identity Services Engine (ISE) cloud deployments on AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI)

  • Vulnerability Description:
    A critical flaw in the credential generation and authorization logic causes multiple Cisco ISE cloud deployments to share identical credentials when using the same software release on the same cloud platform. This allows an unauthenticated remote attacker to extract valid credentials and escalate privileges across different deployments.

  • Expl0it Capabilities:

    • Remote credential disclosure
    • Limited administrative operations
    • System configuration modification
    • Service disruption

Exploitation Method: Network-based, no prior authentication needed

Stability: Fully developed and tested expl0it with detailed deployment instructions

Disclaimer: Intended for authorized research and penetration testing only; misuse prohibited

This repository will be deleted.

Download

entry.content:
æ¼æ´ä¿¡æ¯

æ³¨: æœ¬æ¨¡å—æ¥è‡ª AI å¯èƒ½å­˜åœ¨é”™è¯¯

æ¼æ´åç§°ï¼š Fortinet ç¼“å†²åŒºæº¢å‡ºæ¼æ´

æ¼æ´ç¼–å·ï¼š

  • CVEï¼š CVE-2025-32756

æ¼æ´ç±»å‹ï¼š ç¼“å†²åŒºæº¢å‡º

æ¼æ´ç­‰çº§ï¼š ä¸¥é‡

æ¼æ´æè¿°ï¼š Fortinetäº§å“ä¸­å­˜åœ¨ä¸€ä¸ªä¸¥é‡çš„åŸºäºæ ˆçš„ç¼“å†²åŒºæº¢å‡ºæ¼æ´ï¼ˆCVE-2025-32756ï¼‰ï¼Œå½±å“FortiVoiceã€FortiMailã€FortiNDRã€FortiRecorderå’ŒFortiCameraã€‚è¯¥æ¼æ´å­˜åœ¨äºå¤„ç†/remote/hostcheck_validateç«¯ç‚¹ä¸­çš„encå‚æ•°æ—¶ï¼Œç”±äºè¾¹ç•Œæ£€æŸ¥ä¸å½“å¯¼è‡´ç¼“å†²åŒºæº¢å‡ºï¼Œå…è®¸æœªç»èº«ä»½éªŒè¯çš„è¿œç¨‹ä»£ç æ‰§è¡Œã€‚

äº§å“å‚å•†ï¼š Fortinet

äº§å“åç§°ï¼š FortiVoice, FortiMail, FortiNDR, FortiRecorder, FortiCamera

å½±å“ç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼š FortiVoice: 1.0.0 < version < 7.2.1, 7.0.7, 6.4.11; FortiMail: 1.0.0 < version < 7.6.3, 7.4.5, 7.2.8, 7.0.9; FortiNDR: 1.0.0 < version < 7.6.1, 7.4.8, 7.2.5, 7.0.7; FortiRecorder: 1.0.0 < version < 7.2.4, 7.0.6, 6.4.6; FortiCamera: 1.0.0 < version < 2.1.4

æ¥æºï¼š https://github.com/alm6no5/CVE-2025-32756-POC

ç±»å‹ï¼š CVE-2025:github search

ä»“åº“æ–‡ä»¶

  • README.md
  • fortinet_cve_2025_32756_poc.py
  • requirements.txt

åŸå§‹ä¿¡æ¯

CVE-2025-32756: Fortinet RCE PoC

A proof-of-concept for the critical stack-based buffer overflow vulnerability (CVE-2025-32756) affecting Fortinet products.

Vulnerability

  • CVSS: 9.8 (Critical)
  • Type: Stack-based buffer overflow in AuthHash cookie processing
  • Impact: Unauthenticated remote code execution
  • Affected Products: FortiVoice, FortiMail, FortiNDR, FortiRecorder, FortiCamera

The vulnerability exists in the processing of the enc parameter in the /remote/hostcheck_validate endpoint, where improper bounds checking allows buffer overflow.

Usage

Arguments:

  • target_ip: Target Fortinet device
  • -p, --port: Target port (default: 443)
  • -d, --debug: Enable debug output

Mitigation

Update to patched versions:

  • FortiVoice: 7.2.1+, 7.0.7+, 6.4.11+
  • FortiMail: 7.6.3+, 7.4.5+, 7.2.8+, 7.0.9+
  • FortiNDR: 7.6.1+, 7.4.8+, 7.2.5+, 7.0.7+
  • FortiRecorder: 7.2.4+, 7.0.6+, 6.4.6+
  • FortiCamera: 2.1.4+

Disclaimer

For educational and research purposes only. Use only against systems you own or have permission to test.
